concept.shortdesc: Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.

section.title: Clarity
section.p: A text that is easy to understand is usually also easier to translate. To make your writing clearer, use these tips:

ul.li: Avoid overly long sentences and paragraphs.

Repeat important words to avoid misunderstanding. For example, instead of writing 'If the shaft of your wand breaks, you can get a new one online,' write 'If the shaft of your wand breaks, you can get a new wand online.'
Don't describe more than one action in a sentence unless writing about strictly related actions.
Use words such as "and," "then," "but," "a," "the," "this," and "that" to make your message clear.

section.title: Grammar
section.p: You can make your text easier to understand by using certain grammatical forms. To make your writing clearer, follow these rules:

ul.li: Express actions with verbs, not nouns. For example, instead of writing 'Applying excessive force can lead to rupture of your wand,' write 'If you apply excessive force, your wand can break.'
Split clusters of nouns into smaller logical units. For example, instead of writing 'magic wand cleaning center,' write 'center for cleaning magic wands.'

section.title: Formating
section.p: Search your text for unintended linebreaks and punctuation marks (such as periods in place of commas). Translation tools may misinterpret such characters and split sentences into separate units. This can lead to translation errors and inconsistencies.
Avoid using pagebreaks and empty lines to layout your document. The same content can have a different volume in different languages.
section.note: When localizing a DITA project, always send the translators your source files rather than the output (such as PDF or HTML files).

link.linktext: Importing a DITA project into memoQ
link.desc: Learn how to import your DITA project into memoQ while preserving the project's folder structure.

title.ph: Importing a DITA project into memoQ

task.shortdesc: Learn how to import your DITA project into memoQ while preserving the project's folder structure.

context.p: When translating a DITA project, it is important to preserve the relationships between files. To import your project into memoQ without losing the project's folder strucure, follow these steps:

step.cmd: In the New memoQ project dialog, enter the Name of the project.

image.alt: Choosing a language pair in 'New memoQ project' dialog

step.cmd: Enter the Client and any optional details, then click Next.
In the Translation memories step, choose or create a translation memory.
In the Term bases step, choose or create a term base.
Click … next to the Base path field, choose the folder where your project is located, and click OK.

image.alt: The 'Add folder structure' dialog in memoQ

step.cmd: In the Document import options dialog, remove any files you don't want to translate.

image.alt: The 'Document import options' dialog in memoQ

taskbody.result: Project files are ready for translation. DITA project imported into memoQ To export a translated project, right-click on the root folder and choose ExportExport (Stored Path).

link.desc: Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.
Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.

task.shortdesc: Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.

taskbody.context: If your DITA project contains a lot of repetitive content, it may be useful to include all repetitions in one view. In order to create a view containing all repetitions, follow these steps:

step.cmd: Go to Project homeTranslations and select all files.
Right-click the files and choose Create View.

image.alt: The 'Create View' option in memoQ 'Translations' screen

step.cmd: In the Create view dialog, enter the Name of the view, select Extract repetitions, and click OK.

taskbody.result: You can work on a view containing all repeating segments in your project. An example memoQ view containing repetitions
